text: Transitioning from being a Marine to a civilian was very hard.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I lost my purpose.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I lost the drive that I had.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That is a very dark and lonely place to be.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It took me surrendering to myself to get the help that I needed.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: At my very first Wounded Warrior Project event, I met Ray Pizarro.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He told me, you need to have the courage to forgive yourself for the things you've done in the past.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I got it tattooed on my hand.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One night, my depression kept telling me, you can end this.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And just before I was about to pull the trigger, I looked down at my hand, and that's what saved my life that night.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That was the beginning of my incredible journey with the Wounded Warrior Project.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: See how we help warriors combat stigma at woundedwarriorproject.org.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Hey, it's Dan Bongino.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Let's check in with the top of the hour news and weather on WMIC 660 AM Sandusky and 95.3 FM W237 EQ Sandusky.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is your 4 o'clock news here on WIC-WTV.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm Erica Frisbee.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Snover Road will be closed between Arnold and Wheeler Roads beginning Monday, August 12th for culvert replacement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The detour route will follow north on Germania Road to Deckerville Road, then east on Deckerville Road to Wheeler Road, and then south on Wheeler Road to Snover Road.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In other news, while several incumbents were able to hold on to their seats, yesterday's primary election saw several surprises across the Thumb area, including the defeat of several members of a Tuscola County family.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: With Tuscola County Sheriff Sergeant Ryan Robinson claiming victory in the primary race, outpacing his opponents by at least 1,500 votes, one member of the Putnam family was defeated as Brandon J. Putnam finished third on the Republican ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: However, he wasn't alone in defeat as five members of his family were rejected by Ellington Township voters, having run for four open delegate spots.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While the four non-related candidates earned at least 250 votes each in the delegate race, the votes earned by the five Putnams, when combined, only totaled to 171 votes altogether.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Regarding Tuscola County, voters there passed four millage proposals, including the newest, which will fund a senior citizen home-delivered meal program.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Other proposals approved by voters concerned recycling, senior citizen programming, and the County Sheriff's Road Patrol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meanwhile, San Juan County voters also approved a senior citizen-related millage and decided to pick current Chief Assistant Prosecutor Mark Davison as the next county prosecutor.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Davison defeated Lexington attorney Robert Haybauer, with Haybauer finishing about 714 votes behind Davison, according to unofficial counts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Another close race in San Juan County was that between incumbent county surveyor John Militics, who defeated challenger Ben Tank by less than 500 votes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In Lapeer County's Republican races, the incumbent register of D's during commissioner and road commissioner faced off against challengers, with one incumbent ultimately losing his seat.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While Road Commissioner Jim Novak defeated his opponent Justin Vincent Setti handily, incumbent Registrar of Deeds Amy Stearns had a closer battle with her opponents, finishing only a few hundred votes ahead of challenger Megan M. Lang.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meanwhile, Drain Commissioner Joseph Suma was defeated by challenger Andy Wagner, who outpaced him by over 800 votes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In addition to the candidate races, Lapeer County voters approved the renewal of two millage proposals, one for emergency medical services and the other for Veterans Affairs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While three out of four of the proposals were accepted by voters, St.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Clair County ultimately rejected a proposed millage for additional park funding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The additional parks and recreational millage would have required approval for a .4944 mill to be levied for three years as a mean to raise money for acquiring, developing, and maintaining parks and other related facilities around the county.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but it was firmly rejected with about 54% of St.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Clair County voters voting against the measure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meanwhile, county official incumbents Sheriff Matt King and Clerk Angie Waters both won their respective races, with Waters earning almost twice the number of votes as her opponent Debbie Ryan did.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In Huron County, voters were asked to renew a millage for road funding, with the plan being to renew the millage at a rate of one mill over five years.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Voters agreed to the proposition, voting 4,532 to 1,658 in favor of the measure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That finishes up your 4 o'clock news here on WCWTGV.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Everybody knows that high school sports generate suspense, excitement, and drama.

text: Everybody knows that high school sports give us more value for our entertainment dollar.

text: They also give us leaders committed to strengthening communities right here in Michigan.
speaker: SPEAKER_17

text: The true value of playing sports in school can't be measured in wins and losses or dollars and cents.
speaker: SPEAKER_17

text: Studies show that participation in sports, along with other extracurricular activities, is one of the best ways to teach leadership, cooperation, accountability, and other invaluable life skills.
speaker: SPEAKER_17

text: Don't just stand on the sidelines.
speaker: SPEAKER_17

text: Encourage the young people you know to get in the game.

text: When you do, you'll be helping them get ahead in life.

speaker: SPEAKER_17

text: There's a thing in economics you and I both know called the substitution effect.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You know, price of chicken goes up, people buy more beef.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Price of beef goes up, they buy pork.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You can substitute.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You may not like it, but there's a way out of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's not the case with energy prices.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What you just said is accurate.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There's no way to avoid energy prices if you're going to restrict energy like the Biden administration with Harris are committed to.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There's just no way.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's built into every single thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's right, Dan.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: And that substitution effect, by the way, that happens not only at the local level.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: It happens not only when the individual consumer is choosing, like you mentioned, what kind of meat do I want to buy?
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: It happens at the international level as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: In other words,
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: When we're not producing enough energy exports, countries have to turn to sometimes hostile nations like Iran and buy energy from them.

speaker: SPEAKER_16

speaker: SPEAKER_02
